newsitem.title: UK: New UK government to focus aid effort on poverty.
newsitem.headline: New UK government to focus aid effort on poverty.

text.p: Britain's international development minister on Wednesday promised a ruthless focus on poverty in the new Labour Government's aid efforts, and signalled her determination to avoid links with the arms trade.

Clare Short, whose appointment as a cabinet minister has already heightened the profile of Britain's aid programme, said she planned the first White Paper, or policy document, on the subject for 22 years.
This would make clear the new government's determination to avoid incidents, such as the row over aid to Malaysia's Pergau Dam, which embarrassed the outgoing Conservative administration.

"There will be no more Pergaus. Our intention is to focus ruthlessly on poverty -- getting all children into education and providing clean water and primary health care for all," Short said in a statement.
In 1994, a court ruled that the government acted unlawfully in authorising 234 million pounds ($379 million) in aid for the Pergau dam project.
The government admitted the aid became "entangled" with a one billion pound sale of British arms to Malaysia in 1988.

Short said her presence in the cabinet -- her Conservative predecessor Baroness Lynda Chalker was a junior minister -- was "a statement of intent that the Government will put world development at the heart of its work".

"Isolated acts of charity are not enough. I don't want to play Lady Bountiful. I intend to make a permanent difference," Short, one of the most left-wing members of Prime Minister Tony Blair's government said.
